body_html:
Most likely, somewhere, some resource is periodically over-committed, causing everything else to wait. You might try using the tools described here #1824
to look at the time intervals between operations. However, you could also use other tools to monitor memory use (is anything about your setup causing swapping), hack the code to time individual RPCs and operations at the PS server, and other techniques to look for operations that violate your assumptions about how they should be behaving. If you're doing synchronous steps, look for which operation is last to complete at join points, and try to figure out why.
body_text:

However, you could also use other tools to monitor memory use (is anything about your setup causing swapping), hack the code to time individual RPCs and operations at the PS server, and other techniques to look for operations that violate your assumptions about how they should be behaving.  If you're doing synchronous steps, look for which operation is last to complete at join points, and try to figure out why.
body:
Most likely, somewhere, some resource is periodically over-committed, causing everything else to wait.  You might try using the tools described here #1824 
to look at the time intervals between operations.  However, you could also use other tools to monitor memory use (is anything about your setup causing swapping), hack the code to time individual RPCs and operations at the PS server, and other techniques to look for operations that violate your assumptions about how they should be behaving.  If you're doing synchronous steps, look for which operation is last to complete at join points, and try to figure out why.
